awd_titl_txt: Interactions between Newton-Okounkov Bodies, Cluster Algebras, and Orbit Closures
awd_abstract_narration:
The interplay between combinatorics, which studies with discrete structures, and algebraic geometry, which is concerned with solutions of polynomial equations, has immensely enriched both areas. Combinatorics provides discrete objects that can be used to encode information about an algebraic variety. Conversely, the rich structure of a combinatorial object is often better understood when seen as a discrete shadow of an algebro-geometric phenomenon. The research in this project develops the interplay between these areas utilizing tools which include degenerations of varieties and high-dimensional analogues of polygons.

This project aims to understand various aspects of the interplay between combinatorics and algebraic geometry for Newton-Okounkov bodies, symmetric orbit closures, and subword complexes. Generalizing the relation between polytopes and toric varieties, Newton-Okounkov bodies provide tools from convex geometry to study algebraic varieties. The PI will develop the theory of Newton-Okounkov bodies by constructing combinatorial parameter spaces for these bodies together with a wall-crossing formula. The study of symmetric orbit closures is relevant to the theory of Kazhdan-Lusztig-Vogan polynomials and Harish-Chandra modules for a certain real Lie group, mirroring the connection of Schubert varieties to Kazhdan-Lusztig polynomials and representation theory. The PI will investigate the projections of symmetric orbit closures to Grassmannians. Knutson and Miller introduced subword complexes to study the cohomology of Schubert varieties. The PI will relate these complexes with toric degenerations of Schubert varieties and their desingularizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a strong record of the study of discrete structures leading to advances not only within mathematics, but also in science and industry. This project studied and developed discrete structures arising from the interplay between combinatorics and algebraic geometry. This project advanced the theory of combinatorial varieties and measured polytopes of interest to the combinatorics community. Additionally, efforts were made to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in mathematics through mentoring and organizing a summer school. Lastly, the project included a collaboration with geneticists at a school of medicine. 

Concrete project Outcomes and Findings:

  1. Advancement of Combinatorial Varieties: The Principal Investigator (PI) developed combinatorial, geometric, and algebraic aspects of Hessenberg varieties and Kazhdan-Lusztig varieties. These advancements not only furthered our understanding of the field but also established fruitful connections between various areas of mathematics.
  2. Measuring Polytopes: The PI introduced and measured a new family of polytopes associated with oriented matroids. By connecting these polytopes to existing ones, namely symmetric edge polytopes, valuable insights into their faces, volume, and discrete volume were obtained. This work contributes to the broader understanding of polytopes and their applications.
  3. Broadening Participation in Mathematics: To address the underrepresentation of certain groups in mathematics, the PI undertook initiatives to broaden participation. The PI served as a mentor to underrepresented students, fostering their interest in mathematics. Additionally, the PI co-organized a summer school focused on combinatorics, providing training to undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds.
  4. Support for PhD Training: The project provided support for the training of two PhD students. Through their involvement in the project, these students gained valuable research experience and contributed to the advancements in combinatorics. 
  5. Interdisciplinary Work with the Potential to Benefit Society: In collaboration with geneticists at WUSTL School of Medicine, the PI is developing a very fast combinatorial algorithm to identify novel complex genetic structures driving health and longevity outcomes in humans. Researchers in genetics are using this algorithm to facilitate the rapid discovery of previously unidentifiable genetic structures driving variation in pulmonary function, arterial and cardiovascular health, telomere length, and diabetes. 

In summary, this project has delivered notable outcomes and findings that contribute to the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the field of combinatorics. The advancements in combinatorial subvarieties and measurement of polytopes have expanded our understanding of these areas. Additionally, the efforts to broaden participation in mathematics have positively influenced the representation of underrepresented groups. The support for PhD training and collaboration with researchers in related fields further enhance the project's achievements. Throughout, this project was enriched by interdisciplinary collaborations.
